awd_titl_txt: Integrating functional, phylogenetic and genetic components of diversity for an improved understanding of forest structure, dynamics, and change
awd_abstract_narration:
The species composition and dynamics of forests worldwide are changing in response to multiple factors including deforestation, invasive species, and climate and atmospheric change. The diversity of trees in a forest controls the functioning of the ecosystem, and therefore plays a critical role in regulating forest responses to global change.  This award will support two workshops - one in the US and one in China - to allow scientists to share data and discuss current understanding and future priorities for studying the change in tree biodiversity over time. The workshops will involve approximately 100 participants, 75% of whom will be graduate students, post-doctoral researchers or junior faculty.  Formal international partnerships and informal scientific links will be further developed by these workshops, as well as by international scientific exchanges in which US fellows spend 1-3 months in partner institutions within China. Results of the workshops will be disseminated broadly through peer-reviewed publications, a blog, project website, and other social media outlets.

By combining the largest inventory of tree diversity and dynamics in the world with expanded datasets on species-level functional traits, phylogenies, seed production, seedling regeneration, soil microbial diversity, and tree genetics these workshops will lead to an improved understanding of the dimensions of tree diversity and their role in forest function, and thereby improve predictions of compositional, structural, and dynamic responses to global change.  Two international collaborative workshops will synthesize and integrate: (i) tree functional diversity with species performance to better understand how functional traits control species' performance among environments; (ii) tree functional and phylogenetic diversity to investigate controls on forest ecosystem function; (iii) tree phylogenetic and functional diversity to predict community responses to change from species' performance across environments; (iv) metagenomic surveys of microbial diversity with tree functional and phylogenetic diversity to assess below-ground controls on forest diversity and function; and (v) genetic, functional and phylogenetic diversity to understand the consequences of genetic diversity for species performance. These combined activities will transform current understanding of how forests work, how they are responding to current environmental change, and their resilience in the face of future change.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching research objectives of this grant were to understand how the phylogenetic, functional, and genetic dimensions of diversity are changing in forests, how these changes are related to environmental drivers, and how they affect forest function, dynamics, and resilience.

To accomplish these goals, two annual workshops were held in 2016 and 2017 in association with a CTFS-ForestGEO or CForBio large forest plot. The workshops were held in Hainan, China in 2016 and Puerto Rico, USA in 2017. The main outcomes of these workshops were 119 peer-reviewed publications (plus 17 in the review stage), 129 workshop participants with 75% students and post-doctoral level scientists attending, and web accessibility of data and analytical programs.

The workshops included a total of 129 participants from 20 countries. Approximately 75% of workshop participants were graduate students or postdoctoral fellows. In addition to the workshops, four early career scholars from US institutions (2 post-doctoral fellows, and 2 graduate students) spent 1-3 months at different partner institutions in China for research exchange and to build relationships for future collaborations.

Each of the workshops lasted about 15 days and involved about 65 participants. The workshops were organized into 5 small working groups addressing focused science questions with PIs and senior scientists leading and mentoring each group. Topics included a combination of independent and cross-site investigations. Participants reassembled daily for broader formal and informal discussions and seminars by workshop participants, visiting scientists, and local experts. Workshops culminated in a final day of speed talks that served as progress reports to establish timelines for publication and future work in the coming year.

The project has resulted in 119 peer-reviewed publications, 2 conference reports and one research protocol, with 17 more papers in various stages of review for publication. The papers were published in a wide array of journals, spanning a range of specific disciplines, and including high-ranked journals (e.g., Science, PNAS, Ecology, Ecology Letters, Journal of Ecology, etc.). Many of the papers are multi-authored reflecting the value of data sharing and analysis that is fostered through the workshops. Papers are mainly in English, but are also in Chinese and Spanish language journals illustrating the international impact of this program. Publications have been disseminated through a listserve, blog, Twitter and Facebook pages, website, Flickr site, and Google Scholar.

Major progress on the CTFS R Package was made as a result of this grant. A completely new version of the software, called "fgeo" has been developed in the GitHub framework. Many new tools were added and are continuously being improved, while further annotation of existing tools is being implemented. These developments have greatly expanded the analytical tools available in the program, and broadened access and collaboration with the CTFS-ForestGEO datasets, but also with users of other complementary forest diversity data.

The grant has played a critical role in strengthening the international network of CTFS-ForestGEO, a global forest monitoring and research initiative. Without the opportunity for training and capacity strengthening the network would be far less effective and scientifically productive. The success of international CTFS-ForestGEO network has impacted Smithsonian policies towards long-term observational/monitoring science. The role of the NSF Dimensions grant in supporting the strengthening of the network cannot be underestimated.

The program has also had a large impact on the ability of our international collaborators to access resources and expand the research program of CTFS-ForestGEO plots. This international recognition has released resources for the expansion of the Chinese plots, and created opportunities for additional funding for fellowships and scientific exchange programs. The program has fostered opportunities for many early-career scientists to access further training opportunities through relationships built during this project.
